question: I've heard somewhere that a single serving of cooked pasta equals roughly three cups—can you verify this?
initial_answer:
A serving is a quantity of food suitable for or given to one person in one meal (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8]. Moderation means keeping servings reasonable (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8].

For children:
*   9-12 months: Half a cup at each meal, 3-4 meals per day and 1-2 snacks (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [10].
*   12-24 months: Half of a 250 ml cup/bowl, 3-4 meals plus frequent breastfeeding, based on child’s appetite, 1-2 snacks may be offered (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4], [6], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [10].
final_answer:
A serving is a quantity of food suitable for or given to one person in one meal (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8]. Moderation means keeping servings reasonable (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8].

For children:
*   9-12 months: Half a cup at each meal, 3-4 meals per day and 1-2 snacks (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [10].
*   12-24 months: Half of a 250 ml cup/bowl, 3-4 meals plus frequent breastfeeding, based on child’s appetite, 1-2 snacks may be offered (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4], [6], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [10].

question: Should processed foods be entirely removed from my diet due to harmful chemicals?
initial_answer: Food becomes unsafe for human consumption when the concentrations of hazards are above tolerance levels. These hazards include microorganisms, biological toxins such as mycotoxins, physical materials, and chemical residues (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8]. question: Is drinking at least 12 cups of water daily mandatory for everyone, regardless of size or activity?
initial_answer: A minimum of 2-3 Liters of water per day is recommended for an adult person (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4]. This is equivalent to at least 8 cups a day (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3]. Children should drink all the time as they need (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5].
final_answer: A minimum of 2-3 Liters of water per day is recommended for an adult person (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4]. This is equivalent to at least 8 cups a day (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3]. Children should drink all the time as they need (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5].

state.enhanced_message:
### SOURCE
[1] (Food & Nutrition Handbook) A balanced diet is a feeding pattern that provides adequate amounts of nutrients in their correct proportions as required by the body at a particular time. In order to obtain an adequate supply of nutrients human beings need at least three balanced meals a day in case of adults and at least five meals a day for children. Attaining a balanced diet requires that one: eats various food stuffs in a day, makes careful food choices from different food groups, and eats food in the right proportions and quality as required by the body.

[2] (Food & Nutrition Handbook) Food and Nutrition Handbook for Extension Workers28CHAPTER THREE MEAL PLANNING Meal planning is a process of determining, selecting and preparing foods to ensure a balanced diet for target groups or individ - uals. People will always want to eat food that is acceptable, therefore knowing the consumers’ characteristics, food preferences and location is important in proper meal planning. Common terms used in meal planning A meal is a selection of foods prepared and served in a single serving.

[3] (Food & Nutrition Handbook) In order to obtain an adequate supply of nutrients human beings need at least three balanced meals a day in case of adults and at least five meals a day for children. Attaining a balanced diet requires that one: eats various food stuffs in a day, makes careful food choices from different food groups, and eats food in the right proportions and quality as required by the body. question: I don't enjoy vegetables much; how can I maintain good health without relying heavily on them?
initial_answer: To maintain good health, eat a variety of food types from the three main groups (energy giving, body building, and protective foods) at every meal (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1]. You can get protective nutrients from dark green leafy vegetables and yellow fruits (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6]. Examples of vegetables include dodo, nakati, malakwang, cabbage, and pumpkin leaves (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [10]. Foods like cereals, roots, tubers, starchy fruits and vegetables oils, milk, butter, and ghee are good sources of energy (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8].
final_answer: I don't know.

question: What foods can help improve skin health?
initial_answer: Vitamin A (Retinol) from yellow/orange fruits and vegetables and dark green leafy vegetables (DGLV) ensures healthy skin (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1]. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin) from organ meats, enriched breads and cereals, legumes, almonds, cheese and eggs; also meat, fish, and dark green vegetables promotes eye and skin health (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2]. Beta carotene (pro-vitamin A) is found in dark green and deep yellow fruits and vegetables and maintains healthy skin and hair (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8]. Zinc from shell fish, organ meats and lean red meat, yeast, whole-grain cereals, and legumes is involved in skin health (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9].
final_answer: Vitamin A (Retinol) from yellow/orange fruits and vegetables and dark green leafy vegetables (DGLV) ensures healthy skin (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1]. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin) from organ meats, enriched breads and cereals, legumes, almonds, cheese and eggs; also meat, fish, and dark green vegetables promotes eye and skin health (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2]. Beta carotene (pro-vitamin A) is found in dark green and deep yellow fruits and vegetables and maintains healthy skin and hair (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8]. Zinc from shell fish, organ meats and lean red meat, yeast, whole-grain cereals, and legumes is involved in skin health (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9].

Children should drink all the time as they need (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].

Children should drink all the time as they need (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].

question: How can I manage my sugar cravings despite loving sweets?
initial_answer: Sweet foods such as sugar, jam, cakes and sugary drinks are sources of carbohydrates but should be consumed minimally because they do not provide any other nutrients and may increase risk of overweight (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [7]. You should also avoid eating too much sugar (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5], [8], [9].
final_answer: Sweet foods such as sugar, jam, cakes and sugary drinks are sources of carbohydrates but should be consumed minimally because they do not provide any other nutrients and may increase risk of overweight (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [7]. You should also avoid eating too much sugar (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5], [8], [9].

question: Can you suggest a quick and healthy lunch I can easily prepare for work?
initial_answer:
Here are some suggestions for preparing a quick and healthy lunch:
*   Eat a variety of food types from different main three groups (energy giving, body building and protective foods) at a very meal (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5].
*   Take a fruit and a serving of vegetables (100g or one handful of fresh vegetables) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [3], and [5].
*   Any tuber (Irish potatoes, sweet potatoes, cassava, yams) can be prepared the same way as matooke (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2] and [6]. Dry peas can be prepared the same way as dry beans (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2].
*   Consider a low-cost option like groundnuts, powdered nkejje or silverfish (mukene) powder, and maize flour (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7]. After pounding groundnuts, use half for lunch and keep the other half for supper (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7] and [10].
final_answer:
Here are some suggestions for preparing a quick and healthy lunch:
*   Eat a variety of food types from different main three groups (energy giving, body building and protective foods) at a very meal (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5].
*   Take a fruit and a serving of vegetables (100g or one handful of fresh vegetables) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [3], and [5].
*   Any tuber (Irish potatoes, sweet potatoes, cassava, yams) can be prepared the same way as matooke (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2] and [6]. Dry peas can be prepared the same way as dry beans (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2].
*   Consider a low-cost option like groundnuts, powdered nkejje or silverfish (mukene) powder, and maize flour (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7]. After pounding groundnuts, use half for lunch and keep the other half for supper (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7] and [10].

question: What's the recommended protein intake for someone who doesn't exercise regularly?
initial_answer: The recommended intake of protein each day is about 1 gram per kilogram of body weight (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1]. For example, if you weigh 60 kg (132 lbs), you will require 60 grams of protein each day (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4]. This is equivalent to one egg or a piece of meat about the size of an egg (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4]. Adults need 60-70 g, or about a palm-size piece of meat (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7].
final_answer: I don't know.

question: What non-meat foods are particularly rich in iron?
initial_answer: Whole-wheat products, shell fish, nuts and dried fruit are rich in iron (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2]. Many breads and cereals are enriched with iron (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7]. Other dietary sources include legumes and leafy green vegetables (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
final_answer: Whole-wheat products, shell fish, nuts and dried fruit are rich in iron (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2]. Many breads and cereals are enriched with iron (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7]. Other dietary sources include legumes and leafy green vegetables (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].

question: What's the recommended duration for exclusive breastfeeding?
initial_answer: Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for the first six months of a child's life (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [5], [6], [9], [10].
final_answer: Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for the first six months of a child's life (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [5], [6], [9], [10].

Mothers are advised to breastfeed their babies as many times as the baby demands to be fed (at least 8 times a day, every 2-3 hours). This will help maintain milk production.

[2] (Food & Nutrition Handbook) If you introduce any food before six months you will poten-tially expose the baby to unsafe and poor quality meals. question: What's an immediate effect of malnutrition?
initial_answer: Consequences of malnutrition include increased illness and death, poor growth and development, lower labour productivity, poorer educational attainment, and noncommunicable diseases like diabetes and hypertension (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [5]. Malnutrition increases the risk of death and illnesses and weakens immunity, predisposing individuals to different infections (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7], [8]. More than half of infant deaths are associated with malnutrition (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7], [8].

More than half of infant deaths are associated with malnutrition (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7], [8].

question: Can you explain carbohydrates in simple terms?
initial_answer: Carbohydrates are a primary source of energy in most diets (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], [6], [9]. They include starches, fibre, and sugars (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], [3], [9]. One gram of carbohydrates provides 4 kilocalories (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [5], [8]. Individual carbohydrate requirements vary according to age, sex, physical activity level, and physiological status (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], [4], [8].
final_answer: Carbohydrates are a primary source of energy in most diets (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], [6], [9]. They include starches, fibre, and sugars (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], [3], [9]. One gram of carbohydrates provides 4 kilocalories (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [5], [8]. Individual carbohydrate requirements vary according to age, sex, physical activity level, and physiological status (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], [4], [8].

question: Why is iodine a crucial component of our diet?
initial_answer: Iodine is important for thyroid function and for the mental development of children (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3]. It helps produce thyroid hormones; adequate iodine intake during pregnancy is crucial to normal fetal development (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4], [7]. It makes the brain and body function properly and is essential to the healthy development of unborn babies and young children, and it helps pregnant women (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9].

It helps produce thyroid hormones; adequate iodine intake during pregnancy is crucial to normal fetal development (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4], [7]. It makes the brain and body function properly and is essential to the healthy development of unborn babies and young children, and it helps pregnant women (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9].

question: What's the significance of minerals in our diet?

question: Why exactly does the body require water?
initial_answer:
The body requires water for many functions (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5]:
- To transport nutrients around the body (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5].
- To make blood, saliva, tears, and sweat (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3].
- To enable body processes such as digestion (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1].
- To maintain fluid balance and cell turgidity (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
- To act as a medium for all biochemical reactions in the body and as a solvent for certain nutrients (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
- To remove excreta (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
- To keep some parts of the body moist (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
- To keep the mouth and lungs moist, and to keep the skin moist and cool (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7].
- To produce breast milk, which is also a source of water (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8].
final_answer:
The body requires water for many functions (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5]:
- To transport nutrients around the body (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5].
- To make blood, saliva, tears, and sweat (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3].
- To enable body processes such as digestion (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1].
- To maintain fluid balance and cell turgidity (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
- To act as a medium for all biochemical reactions in the body and as a solvent for certain nutrients (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
- To remove excreta (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
- To keep some parts of the body moist (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4].
- To keep the mouth and lungs moist, and to keep the skin moist and cool (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7].
- To produce breast milk, which is also a source of water (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [7], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8].

initial_answer: Yes, breastfeeding mothers should take a lot of fluids to cater to the high amounts of water used to make breast milk (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], and [3].

question: Why is good nutrition essential?
initial_answer:
Good nutrition is important because it:
- Enhances physical and cognitive development (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], and [3].
- Enhances breast milk production for the mother to adequately breastfeed her child (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and [2].
- Builds and/or boosts body immunity, reducing susceptibility to disease (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1].
- Makes an individual healthy, more productive, and improves the quality of life (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5] and [6].
final_answer:
Good nutrition is important because it:
- Enhances physical and cognitive development (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], and [3].
- Enhances breast milk production for the mother to adequately breastfeed her child (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and [2].
- Builds and/or boosts body immunity, reducing susceptibility to disease (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1].
- Makes an individual healthy, more productive, and improves the quality of life (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5] and [6].

question: What specifically causes night blindness?
initial_answer: Night blindness is caused by vitamin A deficiency (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5].
final_answer: Night blindness is caused by vitamin A deficiency (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5].

[8] (Food & Nutrition Handbook) Vitamin A deficiency, which affects mainly women and children in Uganda, increases the risk of blindness and susceptibility to diseases, mainly diarrhoea and acute respiratory infections in children. Children with vitamin A deficiency are 1.4 times more likely to die of these and other childhood illnesses than ones that are not deficient. Iodine deficiency disorder (IDD), is the single most common cause of preventable mental impairment, brain damage, and physical disabili - ties among children in Uganda.

[9] (Food & Nutrition Handbook) Immediate causes include: - Inadequate dietary intake including poor quality and quantity of food in the diet (poor dietary diversity). - Infection and diseases such as malaria, diarrhoeal diseases, acute respiratory infections, measles and worm infestations. - Low intake of foods rich in appropriate nutrients.

[10] (Food & Nutrition Handbook) Iodine deficiency disorder (IDD), is the single most common cause of preventable mental impairment, brain damage, and physical disabili - ties among children in Uganda. Women with IDDs give birth to children with reduced ability to learn, lower school performance, higher rates of school-age repetition, and poor speech and hearing ability. What is especially tragic is that the effects of iodine deficiency are permanent.

question: Can you clearly explain what a balanced diet consists of?
initial_answer:
A balanced diet is a feeding pattern that provides adequate amounts of nutrients in their correct proportions as required by the body at a particular time (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3].

To attain a balanced diet, one must:
*   Eat various food stuffs in a day (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [4], [5]
*   Make careful food choices from different food groups (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [4], [5]
*   Eat food in the right proportions and quality as required by the body (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [4], [5]

For adults, at least three balanced meals a day are needed, while children need at least five meals a day to obtain an adequate supply of nutrients (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [5]. A variety of foods from the three main food groups (energy giving, body building and protective foods) should be eaten at every meal (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9].
final_answer:
A balanced diet is a feeding pattern that provides adequate amounts of nutrients in their correct proportions as required by the body at a particular time (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3].

To attain a balanced diet, one must:
*   Eat various food stuffs in a day (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [4], [5]
*   Make careful food choices from different food groups (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [4], [5]
*   Eat food in the right proportions and quality as required by the body (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [4], [5]

For adults, at least three balanced meals a day are needed, while children need at least five meals a day to obtain an adequate supply of nutrients (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [5]. A variety of foods from the three main food groups (energy giving, body building and protective foods) should be eaten at every meal (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9].

question: What are some good protein sources aside from animal-based foods?
initial_answer: Legumes and nuts are good sources of plant protein (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3]. Soybeans, peas, cow peas, pigeon peas, common beans, and ground nuts are also good sources of plant protein (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8].
final_answer: Legumes and nuts are good sources of plant protein (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3]. Soybeans, peas, cow peas, pigeon peas, common beans, and ground nuts are also good sources of plant protein (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8].

question: What dietary considerations should pregnant women be aware of?
initial_answer: Pregnant women need to eat more food and should not decrease their intake (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [10]. They require a balanced diet with a variety of foods from the food groups, including one additional meal daily to cater to their physiological needs (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1]. They especially need foods rich in iron and vitamin A (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8], as well as calcium-rich foods like milk and mukene (silver fish) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4]. Pregnant women should also take iron and folate tablets daily to prevent anaemia (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2]. Snacks between meals are also recommended to meet their higher nutrient needs (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2]. On average, women should gain 8-12 kg during pregnancy (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [10].
final_answer: Pregnant women need to eat more food and should not decrease their intake (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [10]. They require a balanced diet with a variety of foods from the food groups, including one additional meal daily to cater to their physiological needs (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1]. They especially need foods rich in iron and vitamin A (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8], as well as calcium-rich foods like milk and mukene (silver fish) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4]. Pregnant women should also take iron and folate tablets daily to prevent anaemia (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [6], (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9], and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2]. Snacks between meals are also recommended to meet their higher nutrient needs (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2]. On average, women should gain 8-12 kg during pregnancy (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [10].

question: Should fruits and vegetables always be washed thoroughly before consumption?
initial_answer: Yes, raw fruits and vegetables should be washed due to the risk of contaminated food or water (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3]. Vegetables should be washed with plenty of water at least three times before cutting (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], [7], and [8]. Washing fruits before slicing and eating them is a main way of preventing infections (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4]. Always wash fruits before giving them to a child (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5].
final_answer: Yes, raw fruits and vegetables should be washed due to the risk of contaminated food or water (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3]. Vegetables should be washed with plenty of water at least three times before cutting (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], [7], and [8]. Washing fruits before slicing and eating them is a main way of preventing infections (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4]. Always wash fruits before giving them to a child (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [5].

question: What foods are particularly good sources of zinc?
initial_answer: Good sources of zinc include beef, seafood, liver, nuts, beans, and whole grains (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2]. Other sources include shellfish, organ meats, lean red meat, yeast, and legumes (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8], as well as dark green leafy vegetables (DGLV), pumpkin seeds, milk, egg yolk, garlic, chicken, and fish (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9].
final_answer: Good sources of zinc include beef, seafood, liver, nuts, beans, and whole grains (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2]. Other sources include shellfish, organ meats, lean red meat, yeast, and legumes (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [3] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8], as well as dark green leafy vegetables (DGLV), pumpkin seeds, milk, egg yolk, garlic, chicken, and fish (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [4] and (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [9].

question: How dangerous can consuming undercooked foods actually be?
initial_answer: Food becomes unsafe for human consumption when the concentrations of hazards are above tolerance levels (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], [4], [7]. These hazards include microorganisms, parasites and biological toxins (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], [4], [7]. Microorganisms are the leading cause of food poisoning in the world (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], [4], [7]. Current practices of food production, postharvest handling, processing, packaging, transportation, retailing and food preparation may lead to food becoming unsafe for consumption (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8], [10]. Food safety related illnesses and problems such as cancer prevalence are now a common occurrence (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8], [10].
final_answer: Food becomes unsafe for human consumption when the concentrations of hazards are above tolerance levels (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], [4], [7]. Microorganisms are the leading cause of food poisoning in the world (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [2], [4], [7]. Food safety related illnesses and problems such as cancer prevalence are now a common occurrence (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [8], [10].

question: Can you provide a simple porridge recipe?
initial_answer:
To make a low-cost porridge for resource-poor households, you can combine cereal and legumes (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3]:
*   90 g (one handful) of cereal (millet, sorghum, maize, rice) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3]
*   90 g (one handful) of legume (beans, peas, pulses, soya) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3]
*   20 g (two tablespoonful) of sugar (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3]
*   1.5 litres (3 nice mugs) of water (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3]

1.  Soak legume overnight, remove testa and boil until soft and mash (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3].
2.  Cook cereal porridge (gruel) as usual (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3].
3.  Add the legume, mix, and simmer for 2-3 minutes (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1].
4.  Add sugar and serve (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1].

Alternatively, you can combine cereal and nuts (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1]:

*   90 g (one handful) of cereal (millet, sorghum, maize, rice) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1]
*   90 g (one handful) of groundnuts, cashew nuts) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1]
*   20 g (2 tablespoons) of sugar (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1]
*   1.5 litres (3 nice mugs) of water (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1]

1.  Toast nuts, remove cover, and pound or grind to a soft paste (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1].
2.  Mix with hot water to make thick soup (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1].
3.  Cook cereal porridge (gruel) as usual (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1].
4.  Add the nut mixture, mix well, and simmer for 2-3 minutes (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1].
5.  Add sugar and serve (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1].

You can also enrich your porridge by adding

question: What's the recommended daily carbohydrate intake for an adult?
initial_answer: Individual carbohydrate requirements vary according to age, sex, physical activity level, and physiological status (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [3], [9]. The recommended daily carbohydrate intake should provide about 45% to 65% of the total body energy/calorie requirements of 2000 -3000 kilocalories (kcal) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3].
final_answer: Individual carbohydrate requirements vary according to age, sex, physical activity level, and physiological status (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [3], [9]. The recommended daily carbohydrate intake should provide about 45% to 65% of the total body energy/calorie requirements of 2000 -3000 kilocalories (kcal) (Food & Nutrition Handbook) [1], [2], [3].
